choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy
CECT abdomen + thorax

questions.text: A 35-year-old Female presented with dysphagia, regurgitation and weight loss. On barium swallow, following appearance was seen. What is the gold standard test to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Esophageal manometry

 

Option C:

 

The above condition is that of achalasia cardia. The barium swallow shows a typical “bird-beak” appearance or smooth tapering.

 

The gold standard for the diagnosis of achalasia is esophageal manometry.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: It is an initial investigation in patients with dysphagia, but not the gold standard.

 

Option B. CECT abdomen + Thorax: It is useful in diagnosis of hiatus hernia but not achalasia.

 

Option D. Barium swallow: This study involves swallowing a contrast (Barium) and X rays are taken.

 

It has largely been replaced by more specific investigations like upper GI endoscopy in patients with dysphagia.

 

Educational objectives:

 

Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows:

 

  • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation
  • Ineffective peristalsis of the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure

 

Achalasia cardia is caused due to the degeneration of the neurons in the myenteric (parasympathetic) plexus of the esophagus. This degeneration results in the failure of relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) on swallowing and ineffective peristalsis in the body.

 

The patients present with a classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods. As the food gets accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis. With further progression of the disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc.

 

The initial diagnosis is made by endoscopy or barium swallow, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak appearance).

 

It is a premalignant condition and can cause squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Page 1121-1122.

choices.text: Dyphagia more towards solids
Decreased diameter of middle esophagus

questions.text: Which of the following is true about achalasia cardia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased esophageal peristalsis

 

Option A:

 

True. Achalasia is characterized by decreased or absent esophageal peristalsis, which means the normal coordinated contractions of the esophagus that help propel food towards the stomach are impaired.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. False. Achalasia is associated with increased lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone. In achalasia, the LES does not relax properly, leading to difficulty in food passage.

 

Option C. False. Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) in achalasia tends to be more pronounced with liquids initially. This is a feature of motility disorders of esophagus.

 

Option D. False. Achalasia does not typically result in a decreased diameter of the middle esophagus. In fact, one of the characteristic findings in achalasia is the dilation or enlargement of the esophagus above the point of obstruction (usually at the LES). This dilation occurs because the lower esophageal sphincter fails to relax properly, leading to a buildup of food and fluids in the esophagus, which stretches and dilates it.

 

Educational objective:

 

Manometric findings suggestive of achalasia:

 

  1. Abnormally elevated Integrated relaxing pressure (IRP)
  2. 100% absent peristalsis, all swallows are either failed or premature.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1122 Fig 66.23

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presented with dysphagia for liquid food more than solid foods. She also complains of regurgitation, halitosis and weight loss. On upper GI endoscopy, there was narrowing at the lower esophageal sphincter and dilatation of the proximal part of the esophagus. What is the definitive modality of treatment for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heller’s myotomy

 

Option B:

 

Heller's myotomy involves surgically cutting the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) muscle to relieve the obstruction and allow food and liquids to pass more easily into the stomach. This procedure can be performed either through open surgery or laparoscopically (minimally invasive surgery).

 

The clinical picture points towards achalasia cardia, for which the treatment of choice is laparoscopic Heller myotomy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Endoscopic Dilation: While this can provide temporary relief of symptoms, it is not considered the definitive treatment for achalasia and may need to be repeated.

 

Option C. Dor's Fundoplication: This procedure is typically performed in the context of treating Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) and is not the primary treatment for achalasia.

 

Option D. Ramstead's Myotomy: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, not achalasia.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

 

Treatment of achalasia cardia:

 

Non-surgical:

 

  • Medications: Sublingual Nitroglycerin or oral calcium-channel blockers
  • Endoscopic pneumatic dilatation

 

Disadvantage: Need for frequent multiple interventions & risk of esophageal perforations.

 

  • Botox injection

 

Symptoms may recur in 50% of the patients within 6 months.

 

Surgical- Treatment of choice

 

  1. Modified laparoscopic Heller myotomy is the operation of choice.
    1. The addition of a partial anti reflux procedure, such as a Toupet or Dor fundoplication, will restore a barrier to the reflux and decrease the severity of postoperative symptoms.
    2.  Advantage: Definite treatment of end-stage achalasia patient
  2. Per Oral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM) is a recently introduced, advanced natural-orifice approach for myotomy. It is preferred for Type III Achalasia (spastic type).
  3. Esophagectomy is considered in any symptomatic patient with the following: tortuous esophagus (megaoesophagus)/sigmoid esophagus.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 27th Ed pages 1095-1099

questions.text: A patient presented with dysphagia to both solid and liquids. Manometry revealed IRP > 15 and >20% premature spastic contractions, but absent peristalsis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Achalasia type 3

 

Option C:

 

In Achalasia type 3, there is a combination of high IRP, pan-esophageal pressurization, and premature spastic contractions, along with the absence of normal peristalsis in the esophagus. This type of achalasia is distinguished from other subtypes (Achalasia type 1 and Achalasia type 2) by its manometric features.

 

Educational objective:

 

Chicago classification 4.0 of esophageal motility disorders based on manometry:

 

Type 1 (Classic): 100% absent peristalsis, high resting pressure of LES.

 

Type 2 Achalasia: 100% absent peristalsis, Pan-esophageal pressurization in >20% of wet swallows

 

Type 3 (spastic): 100% absent peristalsis, Esophageal spasms >20% swallows

 

Jackhammer/Nutcracker esophagus: Hypercontractility > 20% swallows, but peristalsis is present

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Page 1122

choices.text: Diffuse esophageal spasm

questions.text:
A patient presented with retrosternal chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. Barium swallow shows the following:

 

 

What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse esophageal spasm

 

Option C:

 

  • The above clinical picture and manometric findings of corkscrew esophagus are characteristic of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).
  • Diffuse Esophageal Spasm is a condition in which there are incoordinate, premature and rapidly propagated contractions of the oesophagus, causing dysphagia and/or chest pain. The condition may be dramatic, with marked hypertrophy of the circular muscle and a corkscrew oesophagus on the barium oesophagogram.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Achalasia: Barium findings: Barium swallow in achalasia often shows a classic "bird's beak" appearance in the distal esophagus, representing a narrowing at the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), along with dilatation of the proximal esophagus.

 

Manometry findings: In achalasia, manometry typically reveals: Elevated lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure or integrated relaxation pressure (IRP), absence of peristalsis or peristaltic contractions in the esophagus, incomplete relaxation of the LES during swallowing.

 

Option B. Hypercontractile (jackhammer) oesophagus is characterised by high-amplitude contractions and should be differentiated from contractility disorder secondary to outflow obstruction. These abnormal contractions are more common in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. Patients may present with dysphagia or pain. Barium may be normal.

 

Manometry typically reveals: Elevated distal esophageal contractile amplitudes, Normal or slightly elevated lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure, with exaggerated contractions in some segments of the esophagus.

 

Option D. Schatzski ring: Barium findings: Barium swallow may show a narrowing or constriction in the distal esophagus, often at the level of the squamocolumnar junction, creating a "waist" appearance.

 

Manometry findings: Manometry is not typically required for diagnosing Schatzki rings, as they are primarily diagnosed through barium swallow and endoscopy.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hypermotility disorders like nutcracker esophagus (MC type), diffuse esophageal spasm present with dysphagia and are diagnosed on manometry.

 

There is no well-proven treatment strategy for hypercontractile motility disorders. Patients should avoid any identifiable triggering factors (E.g., dietary or GERD related).

 

Similar to achalasia, medical therapy such as calcium channel blockers, nitrates, 5′-phosphodiesterase inhibitors and pain modulators have been used with limited efficacy. Botulinum toxin injection in the oesophageal body may be useful. Long-segment surgical myotomy has been attempted with good results. POEM with extended myotomy is also advocated as a minimally invasive approach to treat these disorders.

 

Ref: Bailey and love 28th edition pg 1125

questions.text: A baby was born to a mother who had polyhydramnios. The mother complains that the neonate is unable to feed properly. There is regurgitation of feeds and frothing of saliva. There are also signs of cyanosis. What is the incorrect statement with respect to the above condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type A is the most common type

 

Option A:

 

The given scenario is suggestive of congenital trachea-esophageal fistula.

 

Type C is the most common variety of congenital trachea-oesophageal fistulas.

 

A trachea-oesophageal fistula is an abnormal connection between the trachea and the esophagus.

 

The main clinical features include: drooling of saliva, inability to pass a NG tube, frothing of saliva.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: On examination, association with VACTERL is often seen. (Vertebral, Anorectal, Cardiac, TEF, Renal and Limb anomalies)

 

Option C: X ray confirms the presence of TEF when coiling of NGT is seen.

 

 

Option D: In type A, there is only atresia without fistula.

 

Educational objective:

 

The presentation is seen at birth. The treatment is always going to be early reconstruction. Type A and B have long gap between atretic segments of esophagus and require esophageal conduits for reconstruction.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 265

questions.text: Which of these is a severity symptom score of Achalasia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Eckardt score

 

Option C:

 

Eckardt Score: The Eckardt score is a clinical score used to assess the severity of symptoms in patients with Achalasia. It grades four major symptoms: dysphagia, regurgitation, chest pain, and weight loss, each on a scale from 0 to 3, with the total score ranging from 0 to 12. Higher scores indicate more severe disease.

 

An ‘Eckardt score’ was developed to assess the severity of symptoms and monitor treatment outcome. Higher the score, more severe is the disease.

 

Components: Dysphagia, Regurgitation, retrosternal pain, weight loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chicago Score: The Chicago Classification is a system used to categorize esophageal motility disorders based on high-resolution manometry findings. It is a diagnostic tool based on pressure measurements within the esophagus.

 

Option B. Allgrove Score: Allgrove syndrome, also known as triple-A syndrome, includes alacrima, achalasia, and adrenal abnormalities.

 

Option D. DeMeester Score: The DeMeester score is a composite score used to quantify acid reflux. It is calculated using data from a 24-hour pH monitoring study and is not specific to Achalasia but rather to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Eckardt score is specifically used to quantify the severity of symptoms in patients with Achalasia, with the score based on the assessment of dysphagia, regurgitation, chest pain, and weight loss.

 

Eckardt score

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1122, table 66.1

questions.text: What is the optimal length of myotomy in Heller’s cardiomyotomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lower esophagus 6 cm, cardia 2 cm

 

Explanation:

 

Heller’s myotomy: Anterior myotomy is performed for at least 6 cm proximally at the oesophageal side and 2–3 cm distally into the gastric cardia. Transabdominal or transthoracic approaches have been advocated. Currently, the standard procedure is a laparoscopic approach.

 

The major complication is GORD, which can occur in up to 40% of patients. The addition of a partial fundoplication (anterior Dor or posterior Toupet) has been shown to be effective in reducing the incidence of GORD.

 

Educational objective:

 

The optimal length of myotomy in Heller’s cardiomyotomy is 6 cm towards Lower esophagus 6 cm and 2 cm towards gastric cardia.

 

Ref: Bailey and Lover 28th Ed. Pg 1124

questions.text: Which of these is not associated with congenital Tracheo-esophageal fistula?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meningomyelocele

 

Option A:

 

Congenital T-E fistula is typically associated with VACTERL abnormalities.

 

Meningomyelocele is not a common component.

 

Educational objective:

 

V - Vertebral defects/Hemivertebrae

 

A - Anorectal malformations

 

C - Cardiac (VSD is MC)

 

TE- Tracheo-esophageal fistula

 

R- Renal agenesis/hydronephrosis

 

L- Limb defects including absent radius, Syndactyly etc.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 264

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with dementia, presented to the OPD with complaints of a fish bone stuck in her esophagus while eating. She is facing difficulty in swallowing. Flexible endoscopy was done to remove the bone, and the surgeon noticed that the foreign body was stuck in the esophagus about 15 cm from the incisors. What is the probable site of the foreign body ?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cricopharyngeal Junction

 

The cricopharyngeal junction is the first physiological narrowing of esophagus, where foreign bodies can get impacted.

 

3 parts where esophagus has physiological narrowing which are measured from upper incisors

 

  1. 15 cm from upper incisors at cricopharynx (narrowest part of oesophagus)
  2. 25 cm indentation of aorta/left bronchus
  3. 40 cm indentation of diaphragmatic crura

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cricopharyngeal junction is the first physiological narrowing of esophagus, where foreign bodies can get impacted

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th ed, Pg 1132

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complaints of vomiting and chest pain. Examination reveals subcutaneous emphysema on chest. The physician suspects Boerhaave’s syndrome. What is the most likely site of injury leading to these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lower third of esophagus.

 

Option C:

 

The most likely site of injury in Boerhaave syndrome is in the lower third of the esophagus. This is the weakest part of esophageal wall.

 

Educational objective:

 

Boerhaave syndrome is the spontaneous perforation of the esophagus caused due to episodes of vomiting against closed cricopharynx. Typically, the site of perforation is the lower oesophagus towards the left pleural cavity. Gastric juice as well as ingested food is forcefully ejected into the left chest. A left pleural effusion rapidly accumulates.

 

Physical examination reveals subcutaneous emphysema on the chest wall, sometimes extending to the cervical region as well. Hamman’s sign refers to a crunching sound on auscultation of the heart owing to surgical emphysema. CT with water soluble oral contrast is diagnostic.

 

Management includes:

 

  1. Treatment aims at adequate drainage, closure of the perforation site within 12 hrs if possible and supportive measures.
  2. If the patient presents late, the perforated part is resected and cervical esophagostomy is done. Feeding jejunostomy is added for nutrition.
  3. Mediastinitis is the most common cause of mortality.

 

Ref: 28th ed. bailey, page 1127-1128

questions.text: An elderly male presents with halitosis and regurgitation of food at night. On examination, there is a gurgling sound on neck palpation. Barium study is as below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pharyngeal pouch

 

Option A:

 

The above clinical scenario and barium swallow is of a pharyngeal pouch/Zenker’s diverticulum.

 

Zenker’s diverticulum is a false pulsion diverticulum as it protrudes posteriorly above the cricopharyngeal sphincter through the natural weak point (the dehiscence of Killian) between the oblique and horizontal fibres of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Plummer Vinson syndrome is characterized by dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs or strictures, but it does not typically present with regurgitation or a gurgling sound on neck palpation.

 

Option C. Dysphagia lusoria is a rare condition where there is compression of the esophagus by an aberrant right subclavian artery, leading to dysphagia, but it does not typically present with regurgitation or halitosis.

 

Option D. Laryngocele is a condition involving a cystic dilatation of the laryngeal saccule, and it typically presents with hoarseness or airway symptoms, not regurgitation or halitosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Clinical features of Zenker’s:

 

  • Pharyngeal dysphagia.
  • As the pouch enlarges, it tends to fill with food on eating, and the fundus descends into the mediastinum.
  • Regurgitation of trapped food can occur and lead to aspiration.
  • Halitosis.

 

Diagnosis: Ba swallow/CT neck with oral contrast

 

 

 

Treatment:

 

Open left cervical incision (most diverticula point towards the left side) with diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeal myotomy. Endoscopic diverticulopexy (Dohlman’s procedure) or stapled diverticulopexy are alternatives.

 

Ref: Bailey and love 28th ed: 1126-1127

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endoscopic stapled diverticulopexy

 

Option C:

 

The procedure is an endoscopic stapled diverticulopexy, done for Zenker’s diverticulum.

 

Newer techniques include transoral introduction of a linear stapler to divide the septum in between the diverticulum and the true oesophageal lumen. This creates a common channel, and the myotomy is performed by the stapler transection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. POEMs procedure (Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy): The POEMs procedure is a minimally invasive endoscopic surgical technique used to treat achalasia, not Zenker's diverticulum. It involves making a tunnel through the inner lining of the esophagus and performing a myotomy (cutting of the muscle) to relax the lower esophageal sphincter, improving the passage of food into the stomach.

 

Option B. Heller’s cardiomyotomy (Heller myotomy): Heller's cardiomyotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat achalasia, not Zenker's diverticulum. It involves cutting the muscle at the lower end of the esophagus (lower esophageal sphincter) to relieve the obstruction that occurs in achalasia.

 

Option D. Stricture dilatation: Stricture dilation involves the use of a dilating balloon to stretch and widen a narrowed or constricted part of the esophagus. This procedure is often used to treat strictures or narrowing caused by conditions such as esophageal cancer, peptic strictures, or eosinophilic esophagitis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Endoscopic stapled diverticulopexy is the procedure depicted in the image for resolving Zenker’s diverticulum.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1127

choices.text: CT with non-ionic contrast swallow study

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of achalasia, had undergone a POEM procedure, following which he developed left sided pleural effusion. A crunching sound was heard on auscultation of the heart. What is your investigation of choice in such a case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CT with non-ionic contrast swallow study

 

Option A:

 

The above condition depicts esophageal perforation following POEM. Iatrogenic perforation secondary to endoscopic procedures such as dilatation of strictures or achalasia is the most common cause. Other endoscopic procedures such as EMR/ESD/ POEM may result in leakage if there is transmural disruption and mucosal defects are not closed properly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. While Upper GI Endoscopy and Option C. Barium Swallow are useful for evaluating esophageal conditions, they are not be the most appropriate initial investigations for assessing a pleural effusion and potential complications after a POEM procedure.

 

Option D. Manometry is a diagnostic test for assessing esophageal motility disorders, but it may not provide the information needed to evaluate the pleural effusion and related symptoms in this case.

 

Educational objective:

 

Gastric juice as well as ingested food is forcefully ejected into the mediastinum following perforation. A left pleural effusion rapidly accumulates. Hamman’s sign refers to a crunching sound on auscultation of the heart owing to surgical emphysema.

 

Contrast swallow study using Gastrografin or a non-ionic contrast usually reveals the site of perforation.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th ed. Pg: 1127-1128

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement with respect to Zenker’s diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zenker’s diverticulum is a true pulsion diverticulum

 

Option A:

 

Zenker’s diverticulum is a false pulsion diverticulum, as it is a mucosal protrusion alone, occuring posteriorly above the cricopharyngeal sphincter through the natural weak point (the dehiscence of Killian) between the oblique and horizontal fibres of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor (option B and C). A true diverticulum is one where all layers protrude, like Meckel’s.

 

As the pouch enlarges, it tends to fill with food on eating, and the fundus descends into the mediastinum. Regurgitation of trapped food can occur and lead to aspiration (option D). Another symptom is halitosis.

 

Treatment:

 

Open left cervical incision (most diverticula point towards the left side) with diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeal myotomy.

 

Educational objective:

 

Zenker’s diverticulum is a false pulsion diverticulum, as it is a mucosal protrusion alone. A true diverticulum is one where all layers protrude.

 

Ref: Bailey and love 28th ed: 1126-1127

questions.text: Identify the investigation and its primary role.
questions.solution:
Ans. B)

Option B:

 

The above image shows the esophageal manometry test. The image shows pressure measurements on Y axis. It is the investigation performed to diagnose motility disorders like achalasia. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 24 Hour pH study involves measuring acid levels in lower esophagus, which is not depicted in the image. 

 

 

 

Option C. 24 Hour pH study is not performed for motility disorders, but for GERD.

 

 

 

Option D. Though esophageal manometry may provide clue to low pressure in lower esophagus, which is associated with hiatus hernia, it is not commonly performed for it. Hiatus hernia is better diagnosed on oral contrast imaging like CT or Barium swallow.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Motility disorders of esophagus are best diagnosed on esophageal manometry.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1121-22

choices.text: Perforation caused by fibre optic endoscopy

questions.text: In which of the below etiology of esophageal perforation is operative management preferred over conservative?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Boerhaave syndrome

 

Option C:

 

Boerhaave syndrome refers to a transmural (full thickness) rupture of the esophagus, often caused by forceful vomiting or retching. This condition is considered a surgical emergency because it can lead to severe mediastinal and pleural contamination. Operative management, which involves repairing the perforation and drainage of any associated fluid collections, is usually the primary treatment approach for Boerhaave syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mediastinum involvement: Mediastinal involvement or extension of the perforation may indicate a more severe case, but whether operative or conservative management is preferred depends on the specific clinical circumstances and the extent of the injury. Surgical intervention may be necessary in some cases with mediastinal involvement.

 

Option B. Cervical perforation: Cervical esophageal perforation may sometimes be managed conservatively with non-operative measures, such as antibiotics and nutritional support, depending on the size and extent of the perforation. However, surgical intervention may be required in certain cases.

 

Option D. Perforation caused by fiber optic endoscopy: Perforations caused by diagnostic or therapeutic endoscopy, including fiber optic endoscopy, are typically managed based on the size and location of the perforation. Small, contained perforations may be managed conservatively with close monitoring, while larger or complicated perforations may require surgical repair

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Perforation of the oesophagus usually leads to mediastinitis. The aim of treatment is to limit mediastinal contamination and prevent or deal with infection.
  • The decision between operative and non-operative management rests on four factors. These are:
  1. The site of the perforation (cervical versus thoraco-abdominal oesophagus).
  2. The event causing the perforation (spontaneous versus instrumental).
  3. Underlying pathology (benign or malignant).
  4. The status of the oesophagus before the perforation (fasted and empty versus obstructed with stagnant residue).
  • Surgical management is required whenever patients are unstable with sepsis or shock; have evidence of a heavily contaminated mediastinum, pleural space or peritoneum; have widespread intrapleural or intraperitoneal extravasation of contrast material.

questions.text: Which of these is an unlikely complication of Hellers cardiomyotomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gas bloat syndrome

Explanation:

Hellers myotomy involves cutting the muscle of the lower oesophagus and gastric cardia.

Option D: Gas bloat syndrome is seen after Nissens fundoplication. The patient complains of gaseous distension of the abdomen and failure to belch or vomit, together with an increase in flatulence. 

 

Option B: The major complication is GERD, which can occur in up to 40% of patients. The addition of a partial fundoplication (anterior Dor or posterior Toupet) has been shown to be effective in reducing the incidence of GERD.

 

Option A and C: Esophageal perforation due to accidental tearing of mucosa and injury to the anterior Vagus nerve during myotomy are possible.

 

Educational objective: Hellers myotomy, the procedure of choice for achalasia (type 1 and 2), is associated with complications like GERD, which may be avoided by adding anti-reflux fundoplications.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1116, 1122-23.

choices.text: Lined mainly by squamous epithelium
Z line represent the gastro-esophageal junction on endoscopy
The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) has both intra-abdominal and thoracic components
The right bronchus causes indentation at 25 cm from incisors

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about esophageal anatomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The right bronchus causes indentation at 25 cm from incisors.

 

Option D:

 

The left bronchus and left atrium/aorta cause indentation on esophagus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While the majority of the esophagus is lined by stratified squamous epithelium, the lower part of the esophagus, particularly the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and the area immediately above it, is lined by a different type of epithelium called gastric or columnar epithelium. This transition from squamous to columnar epithelium is known as the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) and is significant in the context of conditions like gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

 

Option B. The Z-line represents the gastroesophageal junction on endoscopy, where the squamous epithelium of the esophagus transitions to the columnar epithelium of the stomach.

 

Option C. The LES (Lower Esophageal Sphincter) has both intra-abdominal and thoracic components. The intra-abdominal portion of the LES plays a crucial role in preventing gastroesophageal reflux.

 

Educational objective:

 

The left bronchus and left atrium/aorta cause indentation on esophagus and not the right bronchus.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1106-07.

questions.text: Which of these is the preferred treatment for type 3 Achalasia?
questions.solution:
And. C) POEM

 

Option C:

 

Type 3 achalasia, also known as "spastic achalasia," is a subtype of achalasia characterized by vigorous esophageal contractions. POEM is a minimally invasive endoscopic procedure that can be an effective treatment for type 3 achalasia. During POEM, the inner lining of the esophagus is accessed through an endoscope, and a myotomy (cutting of the muscle) is performed to relax the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and improve esophageal emptying. It is considered a less invasive alternative to esophagectomy (Option D) and can provide relief of symptoms in many patients with type 3 achalasia.

 

Explanation

 

Heller's myotomy (Option B) is also a treatment option for achalasia, but it is generally more commonly used for type 1 and type 2 achalasia. Endoscopic dilation (Option A) may be considered in some cases but is often less effective for type 3 achalasia compared to POEM.

 

Educational objective:

 

Treatment of choice for:

 

  • Type 1 and Type 2 Achalasia: Heller’s myotomy
  • Type 3 Achalasia/Jackhammer esophagus/Distal esophageal spasm: POEM with long myotomy
  • Megaoesophagus/End stage achalasia: Esophagectomy

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1124
